questions.question: All of the following diseases are targeted by India for elimination in the future, except?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Neonatal tetanus by 2025 Explanation: India has already eliminated neonatal tetanus in May 2015. The World Health Organization defines the elimination of neonatal tetanus as the incidence of less than one case per 1,000 live births annually in every district nationwide. Elimination of a disease is defined as interrupting modes of transmission of disease in the environment, although the causative agent persists in the community. Diseases that have been eliminated from India. DISEASE YEAR Leprosy 2005 Occurrence of less than 1 case per 10,000 at subnational and district level. Maternal and neonatal tetanus May, 2015 Occurrence of less than 1 case per 1,000 live births annually. Polio Last case in 2011 February 24, 2012 India was removed from the list of polio-endemic countries by WHO March 27, 2014 India is certified polio-free by the Regional Certification Commission (RCC), WHO Dracunculiasis (Guinea worm infection) 2000 Zero cases continuously for three consecutive years. Yaws 2004 Infectious trachoma 2017 Prevalence in children aged 1–9 years of less than 5% , sustained for at least two years without ongoing mass antibiotic treatment, in each formerly endemic district. Diseases targeted to be eliminated from India. DISEASE TARGETED YEAR Kala-azar 2023 by India 2030 by WHO Incidence less than 1 case per 10,000 population at the Block PHC level. Filariasis 2027 by India 2030 by WHO Less than 1% microfilariae carrier rate Measles 2023 Absence of endemic measles transmission in a defined geographical area > 12 months HIV/AIDS 2024 Tuberculosis 2025 Malaria 2030 Zero indigenous cases and deaths due to malaria for 10 years in the whole country Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page: 46 Elimination of Maternal and Neonatal Tetanus in India: A Triumph Tale - PMC NATIONAL STRATEGIC PLAN FOR TUBERCULOSIS: 2017-25 ELIMINATION BY 2025 Elimination of Malaria . NATIONAL FRAMEWORK FOR MALARIA ELIMINATION IN INDIA (2016–2030) Eliminating HIV & AIDS in India: A roadmap to zero new HIV infections, zero discrimination & zero AIDS-related deaths - PMC Eliminating AIDS By 2030 India HIV Estimates 2022: Technical Report Measles

questions.question: Termination of all modes of transmission of which of the following has not been achieved?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Dracunculiasis Explanation: Dracunculiasis (Guinea worm infection) has not been eradicated because all modes of transmission have not been completely terminated. Eradication of the disease refers to the complete termination of all modes of transmission of the disease and is a global occurrence. It exhibits an 'all or none' phenomenon , where the agent is completely exterminated and no longer exists in the environment. Extinction of a disease occurs when, after eradication, the agent is no longer maintained under supervision in CDC or WHO laboratories. Eradication of diseases in India Eradicated Diseases Targeted for eradication Smallpox (1980) Wild poliovirus 2 (2015) Wild poliovirus 3 (2019) Wild poliovirus 1 Measles Dracunculiasis Leprosy Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page: 46, 240

questions.question: Match the following level of prevention with their correct definition. Level of prevention Definition 1) Primary a) Prevention of establishment of risk factors in a population. 2) Secondary b) Prevention of the development of disease in a high-risk group/individual. 3) Tertiary c) Prevention or limitation of disability in a diseased individual. 4) Primordial d) Prevention of the progression of diseases that are in their early stages.
questions.explanation: Correct answer : B) 1- b, 2-d, 3-c, 4-a Explanation: Levels of prevention Definition Primordial Prevention of establishment of risk factors. It aims to discourage people from adopting harmful habits. Avoiding smoking Primary Health promotion and specific protection. Prevention of onset of disease in a high-risk group/individual. It aims to protect the health of those who are at risk. Reduces the incidence of the disease. Quit smoking Secondary Disease progression can be prevented at an early stage (Disease is reversible ). It aims to reduce the prevalence of the disease by early identification and prompt treatment of diseases, and it also prevents complications. Screening for diabetes. Tertiary Prevention or limitation of impairment and disability in a diseased patient who has developed complications due to the disease and the disease has become irreversible. It aims to minimize a patient's suffering and maximize potential years of useful life. Disability limitation and rehabilitation. Quaternary Prevention of the risk of overmedicalization of a patient or population. Aims to prevent prescription of unnecessary medications and invasive medical interventions. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page: 48, 49

questions.question: Which of the following is a mode of intervention for the secondary level of prevention?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Early diagnosis and treatment Explanation: Secondary prevention involves detecting and treating diseases early, before symptoms or complications arise, to prevent progression and minimize health impacts. Early diagnosis and treatment are a secondary level of prevention as the disease has already been established in the patient, but it is in its early stages without any complication, and thus, it is reversible, examples include screening tests for diseases (diabetes). It focuses on reducing the prevalence of disease by prompt treatment and shortening the disease duration. Immunization program (Option A) prevents the onset of infectious diseases through vaccination, a primary prevention strategy . Health education (Option B) promotes knowledge and behaviour change to prevent disease and promote health, a primary prevention strategy. Rehabilitation programs (Option C) aid recovery and restore functioning after illness or injury, focusing on tertiary prevention. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page: 48, 49.

questions.question: Which of the following modes of intervention is not a primary level of prevention?

options.A: Administration of MR vaccination to children
options.B: Examination of school students to identify signs of anemia
options.D: Implementing strict laws regarding drinking and driving

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Examination of school students to identify signs of anemia Explanation : Examining school students to identify signs of anemia is considered secondary prevention because it helps detect the disease early on among those who already have anemia. On the other hand, primary prevention targets the prevention of disease development in the high-risk population. Primary prevention includes: Health promotion: Health education camps on exercise and lifestyle diseases. Mental health promotion and counselling in schools and colleges. Implementing strict laws against drinking and driving to prevent road traffic accidents due to impaired driving (Option A). Specific protection: Administration of MR vaccination to children prevents measles and rubella infection via active immunization, as the risk of infection is high during childhood (Option B). Iodization of salt helps prevent endemic goiter, especially in the Himalayan region, where the diet lacks iodine (Option C). Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page: 48, 49.

questions.question: Choose the correct statements from the following: a)BCG vaccine for TB- primary b)BCG for Ca bladder- secondary c)OCP for contraception- primary d)OCP for PCOD- secondary
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) a,b,c,d Explanation: Secondary prevention focuses on the early detection and prompt treatment of diseases to prevent their progression to more advanced or severe stages. This includes screening and early diagnosis . Primary prevention focuses on interventions to prevent the onset of disease. Level of Prevention Goals Examples Primordial To prevent the establishment of risk factors Lifestyle modification Health promotion Primary Interventions to prevent the onset of disease Vaccinations (statement a) Health education Family planning (statement c) Use of mosquito nets Pre-placement examination Secondary Early detection and prompt treatment of disease to prevent complications Screening tests (e.g., mammograms, PAP smears) Self-examinations Health camps with screening DOTS for TB; ART for HIV; MDT for leprosy. Treatment (statement b and d ) Tertiary Interventions to manage and reduce complications of existing disease to prevent disability or death Rehabilitation Physical therapy Chronic disease management programs Reconstructive surgery Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Page: 48

questions.question: Arrange the following events in the correct sequence: Impairment Disability Functional Limitation Handicap Disease → 1 → 3 → 2 → 4 → 1 → 5 → 4 → 2 → 1 → 2 → 3 → 4 → 5 → 1 → 3 → 4
questions.explanation: → 1 → 3 → 2 → 4 Correct Answer: A) 5 → 1 → 3 → 2 → 4 Explanation: If a patient seeks medical attention at an advanced stage of disease pathogenesis, the interventional approach shifts towards limiting disability. The primary goal is to prevent the progression from disease-induced impairment to a handicapped state. The sequence of events leading to disability and handicap is as follows: Disease → Impairment → Functional Limitation → Disability → Handicap Disease is the initial pathological condition. Impairment refers to a problem in body function or structure. Functional Limitation is the restriction in performing fundamental physical actions. Disability is the restriction or lack of ability to perform an activity in the manner considered normal for a human being. Handicap refers to a disadvantage that limits or prevents the fulfilment of a normal social role for an individual. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Page: 50

questions.question: In a rural village, trachoma remains a significant public health concern. A public health officer is tasked with implementing a comprehensive prevention strategy for trachoma. Match each intervention with the appropriate level of prevention: 1. Primary Prevention a. Coordinates surgical treatment for blindness 2. Secondary Prevention b. Promotes facial cleanliness and sanitation. 3. Tertiary Prevention c. Ensures antibiotics are prescribed only to confirmed cases. 4. Quaternary Prevention
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c Explanation: Levels of Prevention in Trachoma: Levels of Prevention Description Measures Primary Prevention Interventions before the onset of the disease to avert its occurrence by addressing the pre-pathogenesis phase. Promotes facial cleanliness and sanitation to prevent trachoma. Secondary Prevention Aim to halt disease progression in its early stages and prevent complications through timely diagnosis (e.g., screening, case-finding) and prompt, appropriate treatment. Conduct regular eye screenings to detect and treat trachoma early. Tertiary Prevention Focuses on minimizing the impact of existing health conditions by reducing impairments and disabilities , alleviating suffering, and promoting adjustment to irreversible states. Coordinates surgical treatment for those with trachoma-related blindness. Quaternary Prevention Promoting evidence-based practices to prevent over diagnosis and offering ethically validated treatment options Ensures antibiotics are prescribed only to confirmed cases to avoid unnecessary treatment. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Page: 48

questions.question: Which of the following interventions is an example of rehabilitation?

options.A: HPV vaccination in a reproductive-age woman.
options.B: Organising physical therapy sessions for stroke survivors.
options.D: Conducting regular screenings to detect early signs of diabetes-related neuropathy.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Organizing physical therapy sessions for stroke survivors. Explanation: Rehabilitation aims to restore physical function, mobility, and overall quality of life for individuals recovering from stroke-related impairments and disabilities. Disability Limitation Rehabilitation Preventing progression from impairment to handicap. Restoring and maximizing functional abilities. Maintain the current level of function and prevent further deterioration. Achieve the highest possible level of functional independence and quality of life. Targeted medical treatment, assistive devices, and environmental modifications. Coordinated multidisciplinary efforts (medical, social, educational, vocational). E.g. Medical treatment. Assistive devices. Environmental modifications. E.g. Organizing physical therapy sessions for stroke survivors. HPV vaccination in a reproductive-age woman (Option A) is a primary prevention against HPV infection and associated cancers. Administering insulin to manage diabetes (Option C) is a tertiary prevention method that manages complications and improves the quality of life in diabetes patients. Conducting regular screenings for early signs of diabetes-related neuropathy (Option D) is an example of secondary prevention aimed at early detection and intervention to prevent complications in individuals with diabetes. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Page: 50-51

questions.question: For which of the following diseases is mass prophylaxis more commonly employed than mass treatment?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Cholera Explanation: Mass prophylaxis is more commonly employed than mass treatment for cholera due to the effectiveness of oral cholera vaccines in preventing outbreaks. Mass prophylaxis Mass Treatment Description It involves administering preventive treatment to an entire population to prevent disease occurrence. It involves treating an entire population or community to control or eliminate a disease. Level of prevention Primary prevention strategy. (To prevent disease onset in individuals who have not yet been infected). Secondary prevention strategy. (Aim to reduce the prevalence of a disease and prevent further transmission). Examples Mass vaccination during outbreaks to prevent the spread of diseases such as: Cholera Hepatitis A Lymphatic filariasis (Anti-filarial drugs) Malaria (Anti-malarial drugs) Onchocerciasis (Ivermectin) Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Page: 46

questions.question: Which of the following international declarations or charters is primarily associated with outlining the principles and strategies for health promotion?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Explanation: The Ottawa Charter is the foundational document for health promotion, outlining key strategies and principles such as building healthy public policy, creating supportive environments, strengthening community action, developing personal skills, and reorienting health services. The Declaration of Alma-Ata (Option A), adopted in 1978, aimed to achieve Health for All by 2000 through Primary Health Care (PHC). Key points include: PHC is essential, accessible, and community-based health care. Recognition of health as a human right with a focus on equity. Emphasis on community participation and inter-sectoral collaboration. Call for global support and cooperation to strengthen health systems, especially in developing countries. The Jakarta Declaration on Health Promotion (Option B) (1997) set a vision for health promotion in the 21st century, emphasizing that the determinants of health include peace, shelter, education, social security, social relations, food, income, women's empowerment, a stable ecosystem, sustainable resource use, social justice, human rights, and equity. Helsinki Declaration (Option D) is primarily concerned with ethical principles for medical research involving human subjects, not health promotion strategies.

questions.question: Which term describes the systematic collection, analysis, and interpretation of health data for the planning, implementing, and evaluating public health practices?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Surveillance Explanation : Surveillance is the systematic collection, analysis, and interpretation of health data to plan, implement, and evaluate public health practice. Surveillance can be active, passive, sentinel surveillance Monitoring (Option A) involves the continuous (short-term) measurement and analysis of specific parameters or indicators related to the environment, population health status, performance of health services/professionals, patient compliance, or activity implementation. It is the analysis of daily routine activities, process-oriented, and done internally. Evaluation (Option C) is the systematic assessment of an intervention or program's design, implementation, and outcomes. It is a periodic assessment that is outcome-oriented and conducted via an external audit. Impact Assessment ( Option D) evaluates the effects or outcomes of an intervention or policy on a population or environment. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Page: 46-47

questions.question: Which surveillance method involves routine reporting and data collection without active efforts to enhance reporting?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Passive surveillance Explanation: Passive Surveillance relies on routine reporting from healthcare providers or institutions without additional efforts to enhance reporting Active Surveillance (Option A) involves proactive data collection, where health authorities actively search for cases of diseases. The 4 diseases that are actively screened in India: Polio: AFP (Acute Flaccid Paralysis) by SMO (Senior Medical Officer) Malaria: By MPW (Multipurpose Worker) Kala Azar (Visceral Leishmaniasis): Depending on the region or program specifics, various healthcare personnel may be involved in the surveillance and reporting. Tuberculosis: By ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) worker Sentinel Surveillance (Option C) involves monitoring a specific subset of the population or healthcare facilities representing the larger population. E.g., HIV/AIDS screening done in ANC, Blood banks, and STD Clinics. Syndromic surveillance (Option D) monitors non-specific health indicators or syndromes (e.g., fever surveillance for malaria, cough for 2w for TB, Flu symptoms for COVID) to detect potential outbreaks or public health emergencies early, analyzing symptom data patterns. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Page: 47

questions.question: What is the main objective of evaluating healthcare establishments?

options.B: Assessing the efficacy and efficiency of health services

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Assessing the efficacy and efficiency of health services Explanation: The objectives of evaluating Healthcare establishments: The main objective of evaluating healthcare establishments is to assess the efficacy and efficiency of health services. This evaluation helps determine how well healthcare services are being delivered, whether healthcare goals are being met, and whether resources are being utilized optimally. It involves examining the quality of care provided, patient outcomes, and the cost-effectiveness of the services. While monitoring patient satisfaction levels is important, it is just one aspect of the overall evaluation process aimed at improving the effectiveness and efficiency of healthcare delivery. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Page: 47

questions.question: Which of the following measures is implemented for individuals who are already ill and potentially infectious?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Isolation Explanation: Isolation separates individuals who are already ill and potentially infectious from others for the maximum period of communicability to prevent disease spread. It can occur either in healthcare facilities or at home, depending on illness severity and resource availability. It is a defensive strategy. Quarantine (Option B) separates and restricts the movement of individuals exposed to a contagious disease for a maximum known incubation period, but not yet symptomatic to monitor for symptoms and prevent potential disease spread upon becoming infectious. Isolation and quarantine are examples of primary prevention. Social distancing (Option C) is a public health measure involving maintaining physical distance and avoiding crowded places or gatherings. It aims to prevent the transmission of infectious diseases but applies broadly, not specifically to individuals already ill. Contact tracing (Option D) is the process of identifying and monitoring individuals in close contact with an infected person. It is used to identify potential secondary cases and implement appropriate measures, such as quarantine or testing, to prevent further transmission. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Page: 132
